positive_phenotypes: Clinical phenotypes associated with the positive probands are moderate ID, microcephaly, ataxia, speech impairment, and aggressive behavior.
Listed under the 'Clinical features' section, starting from the line 'Family 1-III:4'.
Clinical phenotypes associated with the positive probands. The affected individuals in this family have moderate ID, athetosis, aggressive behavior, speech impairment, muscular weakness, and ataxia.

Clinical features associated with the positive probands. The report mentions that 'Table 1 for full description of clinical features'. This suggests that the clinical features are mentioned in Table 1, but the actual details are not provided in the text.
Clinical phenotypes associated with the positive probands. However, there are no positive probands in this report.

The clinical phenotypes associated with the positive probands are described in the DISCUSSION section of the report. The phenotypes include moderate ID, speech impairment, seizures, ataxia, and muscular weakness.

Clinical phenotypes associated with the positive probands include autosomal recessive intellectual disability, Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease type 2N (CMT2N), Alpers syndrome, peripheral neuropathy, GABAergic neuron loss in the hippocampus and cerebral cortex, and seizures.

The number of individuals reported to have compound or double heterozygous mutations. This is stated in the section: 'Compound heterozygous WARS2 mutation in family 2'.

A compound heterozygous genotype was found in affected individuals, consisting of a deleterious frame-shift mutation and a missense change (p.Trp13Gly) in the mitochondrial tryptophanyl-tRNA synthetase encoding WARS2. This is mentioned in the DISCUSSION section of the report.
No individual was reported to have compound or double heterozygous mutations.
